title: Thursday, 5th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hello, then.

BE11:04am

Slightly all over the place this morning, apologies in advance.

BE11:05am

So .......... have a picture.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

He's updated his Linkedin, at least.

BE11:07am

Though the company hasn't yet updated its board of directors page.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

http://www.accrol....oard-of-directors/

BE11:08am

... to reflect the rather buried news of September 7 that Steve was "stepping down from the Board with immediate effect to pursue other interests."

BE11:08am

And less than a month later, this happens: https://www.invest...1710050700047536S/

11:08 am
BE11:08am

· Continued increases in input costs are being driven by parent reel price inflation. In particular, there has recently been a further material rise in parent reel prices.

· The anticipated inflation recovery through product price increases has delivered less than planned to date. In addition, the delay in price increases will have a reduced positive impact on the current financial year.

· The Company has also incurred higher than anticipated costs in relation to the operational changes associated with preparing the business for growth. The Company believes these changes will deliver improved performance over the longer term.

BE11:09am

Which is all pretty bad. But, as Kadhim notes on the main blog this morning, it gets worse.

BE11:09am

· The Board has recently been advised that a Health and Safety incident, which occurred prior to the Company's AIM IPO, may now result in a more significant fine being imposed by the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) than was previously anticipated. Whilst this is not expected to impact on trading, based on advice received by the Company's legal advisers, any resulting fine may have a material impact on the Company's cash position.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

So .......... let's spin over to the Aim admission doc maybe?

BE11:10am

11. Litigation There are no governmental, legal or arbitration proceedings in which any Group Company is involved or (so far as the Directors and the Proposed Directors are aware) which are pending or threatened by or against any Group Company, in each case which may have, or have had in the twelve months immediately preceding the date of this Document, a significant effect on the Company’s and/or the Group’s financial position or profitability

BE11:10am

................... hm.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

A surface reading of that does look kinda bad for Zeus, the Nomad.

BE11:11am

It also looks kinda bad for Northedge, who took this thing private in 2014.

BE11:12am

And it looks quite bad for Steve, who might need to give a bit more detail on which other interests he needed to pursue with immediate effect.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Anyway, shares suspended.

BE11:13am

Liberum, I think, were pulled in as joint house broker about a month ago.

PM11:13am

Sheesh

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Here's Wayne Brown, saying nothing.

BE11:14am

In a very disappointing and rather unforeseen set of circumstances we are putting our forecasts and recommendation under review. The shares have been suspended pending funding discussions with the company's lenders. We will update our views and forecasts as and when there is greater clarity.

BE11:14am

And let me check if there's anything from Zeus.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Bit late to go 'under reivew'

PM11:15am

It's suspended

BE11:15am

Probably looked like a good client win this time last month. Nice safe boring bog paper maker.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

hehehe

BE11:16am

Nothing from Zeus in my inbox, disappointingly. Anyway, we can add it to the long list of impositions soon after flotation by a private equity owner.

BE11:16am

Bagir was a classic, for example. This rivals it.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:17am

So, where to begin among the functional companies?

PM11:18am

There are bits and pieces around

11:17 am
PM11:18am

But not reflected at the index level

PM11:18am

Where's the Footsie?

PM11:18am

Up 11 points or so

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Yup, flattish again. We're in a holding pattern at the moment.

PM11:20am

Seen this Vodafone stuff

BE11:20am

.............. The brand repositioning stuff? I can't say I read it.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

https://www.invest...1710050700057483S/

PM11:20am

They are no longer the Power to You

PM11:21am

Instead they're gonna be...

11:20 am
PM11:21am

The future is exciting. Ready?"

BE11:21am

..................... I see.

PM11:21am

The first part of the strapline will be presented in local languages with the second part - "Ready?" - presented in English. For example: "il futuro è straordinario. Ready?" in Italian; and "El futuro es apasionante. Ready?" in Spanish.

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Also

PM11:22am

The logo will also appear in a new 2D design in place of a skeuomorphic 3D approach

BE11:22am

skeuomorphic?

11:22 am
PM11:22am

What kinda word is that?

PM11:22am

It's something you might come out with

PM11:22am

Skeuomorphism is the design concept of making items represented resemble their real-world counterparts. Skeuomorphism is commonly used in many design fields, including user interface (UI) and Web design, architecture, ceramics and interior design.

11:22 am
PM11:23am

Now we know

BE11:23am

Oh, right, it's like when the buttons on your phone screen look like actual buttons.

BE11:23am

That's super. I'm assuming the stock's on fire as a result.

11:23 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 209.25, up 0.15 (+0.07%), High: 210.55, Low: 209.24, Volume: 11.84m
BE11:23am

Oh.

BE11:25am

(@Mouselet: yes - https://www.bloomb...ocus-to-blockchain )

11:25 am
undefined
BE11:25am

So back to happenings.

BE11:25am

DFS mentioned on the right.

11:25 am
DFS Furniture PLC (DFS:LSE): Last: 215.75, down 9.25 (-4.11%), High: 218.25, Low: 209.75, Volume: 300.98k
BE11:25am

FY results are at the bottom end of the range.

BE11:26am

And remember that 9.5p special divi DFS paid earlier in the year?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Well, it's pushed debt up to £144.5m, or 1.75x

BE11:27am

Against management's 1.5x target. So, um, well done.

BE11:27am

Current trading's pretty poor

11:27 am
BE11:27am

LFL's slightly negative

BE11:28am

That's compared with SCS doing 3% LFL so there's an argument to say it's company specific.

BE11:29am

That's been Peel Hunt's thesis for some time. You might remember the stuff they did recently about search trends and such.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here's what they say this morning.

BE11:29am

The prelims were predictably grim and the outlook statement suggests that any profit growth will be very second half weighted. Whilst we have no doubt that some of the strategic advances that DFS is making are showing progress, we continue to believe that LFL growth will be difficult to come by, and with operational gearing relatively high here, we find ourselves below consensus and guidance. That lower EBITDA forecast leads us to believe that the pressure on the dividend will increase as well. The valuation is high enough given the risk to consensus numbers and we persist with our REDUCE recommendation.

BE11:30am

Management created a range for EBITDA of £82m-87m with the profit warning in June and then guided towards the bottom of the range in August, so it shouldn’t have been a surprise that £82m was the outcome (although for some reason consensus had stuck at £84m). Gross margins were under fierce pressure in H2, and the lower sales growth made it very difficult to find mitigation. The same is true of costs: management is talented at sailing through choppy waters and it is likely that its skills will continue to be tested in FY18.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Given that the EBITDA outcome was
largely known, all eyes went straight to the outlook statement. It is disappointing
that LFL remains in negative territory (although not as bad as it was in H2): we say that as SCS, John Lewis and Dunelm (not precise comparators we accept) had recently suggested that the late summer/early Autumn had been quite a bit
better in trading terms. DFS continues to believe that it will outperform the wider market this year, and that may well be the case if new stores and additional sq footage is considered. DFS is of course perfectly entitled to make the best of its real estate and capital, but a better measure of progress is LFL share gain and we expect that this will be hard to come by this year. We expect -4% LFL in H1, with it moving to flat against the easy comp in H2. We’d say that the risk was to the downside in H1, and to the upside in H2, but there is going to be serious pressure to deliver in H2 if modest profit growth is to be delivered this year. Indeed, with the crucial Boxing Day sale falling in H1, if our numbers are right, H2 EBITDA will have to rise by nearly 20% to deliver management guidance. We think that’s a stretch.

BE11:31am

Acquisition put dividend under pressure. The acquisition of Sofology makes strategic sense in that it opens up the younger and more affluent market to DFS (although in fairness progress is being made in that area in core DFS stores anyway). Its EBITDA record has been chequered of late but there are clear synergy opportunities and the cash spend on the business will probably eventually be about £50m, That puts short-term leverage under pressure if our forecasts for lower EBITDA are right: the dividend may or may not be cut but it would be wrong to write in an unchanged dividend in too indelible an ink. DFS is a perfectly solid company, but the valuation doesn’t reflect the headwinds.

BE11:31am

Jonathan Pritchard and John Stevenson are the analysts there, who we quote quite a lot here.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

On the less bearish side of things there's Stifel.

BE11:32am

Despite a challenging environment for bigger-ticket items, DFS remains a quality retailer with a dominant market position, vertical integration and multi-channel capability. The low (absolute and relative) valuation reflects challenging current trading. We expect the shares to recover as consumers' disposable income headwinds ease in H2 FY18. The shares should be of particular interest to income-focused investors, given an above average Ordinary dividend yield,10% FCF yield and the potential for additional distributions into the medium term.

BE11:32am

And Jefferies, which is house.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Stock trading on 12x our new cal 18 EPS; increase PT to 240p. The market backdrop will remain a challenge but as market leader we expect DFS to outperform peers given scale and its flexible cost base. The potential Sofology acquisition is exciting (from a cost and revenue perspective) and we estimate the deal could be c.4% accretive to EPS in FY19E with £4m near-term synergies expected by management (current DFS forecasts based on standalone). We move our target multiple to 12.5x cal 18e PER and increase our PT to 240p on what we expect to be trough earnings.

undefined
BE11:04am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Thumbs up

PM11:34am

What else?

BE11:34am

Um .................. there's Merlin.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Leading us up for reasons that escape me.

Merlin Entertainments PLC (MERL:LSE): Last: 459.00, up 10.6 (+2.36%), High: 459.20, Low: 448.00, Volume: 1.04m
BE11:35am

Bloomberg reporting overnight that it's looking at bits of Seaworld.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Along with other interested parties. Seaworld up 11% overnight.

PM11:36am

https://www.ft.com...-9999-ae9f22659b53

BE11:36am

Now, without any detail on which bits and how much it's very hard to come to any kind of opinion about this.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

What we can say is that Merlin looks at a lot of acquisitions, and doesn't buy many.

BE11:37am

I've heard it suggested, for instance, that it took a very close look at Kidzania a few years ago.

BE11:38am

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KidZania

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Is that a thing? Kidzania

PM11:38am

"An indoor city run by kids"

BE11:38am

It is. Though my sources close to the one in Westfield suggests it's a thing in decline.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Because tourist footfall isn't that great and it's a bit too expensive for the repeat visitor numbers you get from those soft play hit-each-other-with-foam-bats things.

BE11:40am

Anyway, I believe Merlin decided that Kidzania's owners were wildly optimistic on valuations and decided to walk.

PM11:40am

Meanwhile, SeaWorld -- that's had a few reputational issues...

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Ueah, so we're probably talking about Busch Gardens parks rather than the fish.

PM11:41am

Oh, ok

BE11:41am

In fact, Merlin said as much during the H1 call

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Not killer whale shows

BE11:41am

Yep. Which makes Bloomberg's story a bit .... incremental, I guess?

BE11:42am

Here's Barclays.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Prior to becoming a public company, Merlin was very active in M&A but since listing there have been no significant transactions. At the time of the IPO management stated M&A as one of its 6 strategic growth objectives and the criteria was a 20% synergized EBITDA ROCE on any transaction. As a result of this the group has walked away from transactions such as the Singapore Flyer on the ground that the price was too high and this ROCE couldn’t be justified. More recently Merlin’s language has evolved slightly when talking about ROCE to allow for other factors such as tax breaks which can be added attractions to a deal that are not captured in EBITDA ROCE. In this context we have heard management refer to a c14% IRR target (which is expected to be fairly consistent with the 20% ROCE).

BE11:42am

Seaworld (covered by US analyst, Felicia Hendrix) does not break out Revenues/EBITDA for the Busch parks but these represented c37.5% of SEAS attendance in 2015 (last reported). Closing EV according to Bloomberg was $2.8bn though the shares were indicated +11% in the aftermarket which would imply c$3bn EV. A crude analysis based on these two facts alone points to a valuation of c$1.1bn (before any further premium which would be likely) or c£840m.

Regarding leverage management has stated that it is happy with Net debt/EBITDA of 2-3x. We forecast 2018 ND/EBITDA of 2.4x which means the group has c£850m headroom for as deal to the upper end of this range.

BE11:43am

Barclays also interesting from the Seaworld angle.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

SEAS fundamentals have been in decline since 2013. Assuming our 2017 estimates are correct, adjusted EBITDA and attendance will have declined 32.8% and 10.9%, respectively, in this timeframe. As the company continues to underperform quarter after quarter, we unfortunately do not foresee an easy path to recovery anytime soon.

BE11:43am

As such, it’s almost a no brainer, in our view, that SEAS has been a recent subject of activist/break up talk. Based on our analysis, we find that any breakup scenario as suggested by Bloomberg headlines yesterday (Legoland Owner Merlin is Said to Approach SeaWorld Over Deal) leaves current SEAS shareholders hardly better off in terms of valuation.

BE11:44am

So, there's kinda sense to Seaworld selling Busch and using the cash to pay off debt.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

But it's a crown jewels move.

BE11:45am

At the end of the day, we think a sale of Busch Gardens is an interesting prospect that could drive value for shareholders down the road. However, there is execution risk that should be considered, and we don't think a sale is going to be easy. Our analysis makes valuation assumptions that may not work for a corporate buyer like Merlin (mentioned in the press) with stated EBITDA ROCE goals of 20% post-synergies or others in the sector despite trading at similar or higher multiples. Of course, there could always be interest from foreign buyers or private equity who may be willing to pay more.

BE11:46am

And back to Merlin again. Here's Credit Suisse.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

We see this fitting well within the group's strategic
framework as i) it represents a strategic acquisition, ii) the Virginia park could be a potential Legoland (note Legoland Florida was a conversion from an existing theme park); iii) there is scope to add accommodation making Busch Gardens short break destinations, iv) the lack of capital under SeaWorld's ownership may give scope for greater investment in the existing parks and v) it broadens the group's geographic exposure – a further stated aim of management. Assuming Busch Gardens accounts for 32% of SeaWorld EBITDA (in line with visitor mix), an acquisition multiple of 10x 2018E EBITDA and a 3% margin funding cost, we estimate a deal would be 7% EPS accretive in 2018E. We flex assumptions within the note. The estimated earnings accretion makes no allowance for improved operational performance, capital investment or an enhanced accommodation focus.

BE11:47am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:47am

SeaWorld does not report the profitability of the two parks, but we estimate they generate EBITDA of c. $100m, based on the parks' c 7m visitors being equivalent to c 30% of SeaWorld total visitors and therefore EBITDA. Assuming a 9-11x EBITDA multiple (in line with other theme parks' trading multiples, and above SeaWorld's recent trading levels, as the parks are superior quality assets than the rest of the portfolio) implies a potential valuation of around $1bn, and we think this could be debt-funded as it would take the company from 2.6x to c 3.5x leverage pre synergies, and on a glide path to its 2-3x target. It could also be nicely EPS accretive on these assumptions. Merlin has a good track record of turning around underperforming assets, and already has 2 LEGOLAND Parks in the US, including the Cypress Gardens park, which it acquired and turned around in 2010.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And that's probably enough.

undefined
BE11:49am

Turning to requests ...........

11:49 am
BE11:49am

We have BTG.

BE11:49am

Buying Roxwood Medical for up to $80m and reiterating guidance.

BE11:50am

Diversifying further from its core hovercraft business.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Here's Panmure.

BE11:51am

BTG interim trading update in slightly ahead of our expectations, with double digit CC growth seen in the first half. Guidance on products reiterated for the full year with licensing revenue expected to be slightly better than indicated. Guidance assumes mid to high teens growth from Interventional Medicine (PG est 21%) and Specialty Pharmaceuticals low to mid-single digit (PG est 2.5%). Licensing revenue in H1 has benefited from Lemtrada royalties and this is now expected to decline more slowly than previously indicated in H2. We currently have no sales from Lemtrada in the second half in our forecasts. We expect to update our forecasts shortly

BE11:51am

TG also announces it has acquired Roxwood Medical a provider of advanced cardiovascular specialty catheters used in the treatment of patients with severe coronary and peripheral artery disease. BTG will pay $65m on closing plus up to an additional $15m on future commercial milestones. The acquisition is expected to be earnings enhancing from the second full year of ownership. This bolt –on acquisition fits with the BTG strategy of continuing to acquire additional interventional medicine products to add to its current portfolio. The company is sufficiently cash generative to fund this type of acquisition out of cash flow. The minimally invasive technology fits alongside the current EKOS products, and will be sold through the existing EKOS sales force.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

The EKOs products are used for treatment of blood clots. Two new sets of data were published from clinical studies with EKOS earlier this year demonstrating of the device in different applications (short lower dose therapy for pulmonary embolism and use in post-thrombotic syndrome) offering the potential for label expansion. EKOS was the fastest growing segment of Interventional Medicine in FY 2017 and we expect this to continue. The addition of the Roxwood products to this portfolio should further accelerate growth from this subdivision.

BE11:53am

And not much to say.

undefined
11:54 am
PM11:54am

Any movement in Whitbread?

PM11:54am

I just notice that Morgan Stanley are saying Britain could squeeze in another 500 Costas

PM11:55am

I'd rather we didn't.

11:55 am
PM11:55am

Costa overindexes in small towns, and underindexes in large populations, and our "reinforce, invade, colonise" cluster analysis suggests potential for 500+ additional UK stores, implying 25%+ to EBIT. While expansion will slow post 2020, investors are only paying ~4x EBITDA for Costa.

PM11:55am

Oh, look at this

PM11:56am

With weak LfL sales and mounting concern over market saturation, we look into how much more room Costa Coffee has to expand in the UK. Morgan Stanley's AlphaWise team sourced the locations of Costa and its competitors, split the market into 6 clusters, and assessed its potential to "reinforce" (existing presence but low market share), "invade" (no presence, but branded competition established), and "colonise" (no branded coffee shops but a market opportunity based on minimum population levels). Please ask for our model.

11:56 am
PM11:57am

We think Costa has room for ~530 additional stores in the UK, equating to ~4 years of growth. Our estate analysis shows that Costa has greatest market share in smaller wards in the UK: almost 70% share in the smallest towns compared to 20% in the most active urban centres. Over 60% of the expansion opportunity (greater than 300 stores) would be for Costa to gain a presence where its competitors have one and it does not, suggesting low cannibalisation risk. A further 30% (greater than150 stores) could be gained by reinforcing its position in areas where it already has a presence, but its market share is lower than we would expect.

PM11:57am

Minimum 25% upside potential to EBIT ... This suggests ~2,600 stores, close to its target of 2,500. It is also equivalent to Starbucks' density in the US. Assuming current average UK equity/franchise Costa store economics of £70k EBIT, these units could add £37m or 25% to EBIT, but 50% more if they were all equity stores. Our work does not consider upside from more sites at travel hubs and Drive Thrus which are larger units with less high street exposure. And we exclude upside from Express machines and International (where there is much to prove).

... but much relies on LfL sales. If LfL sales weaken further, whether due to the UK economy, the c40% of stores on the high street, or competition, we wouldn't rule out Costa slowing its expansion, despite there being a clear opportunity.

PM11:58am

They have a 47 quid target price for whitbread

11:58 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,866, up 21 (+0.55%), High: 3,896, Low: 3,833, Volume: 241.16k
undefined
BE11:59am

What else we got? There's Allied Minds, which is now a smallcap.

11:59 am
Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 164.19, up 15.44 (+10.38%), High: 164.19, Low: 141.50, Volume: 245.49k
BE12:00pm

Spin Transfer Technologies has secured $22.8m convertible bridge financing underwritten by Allied Minds.

PM12:01pm

This is the memory chip thing

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Worth $$$$ if the tech is adopted -- but they need to monetise something in their portfolio

BE12:02pm

Has a 49% stake, which accounts for about a third of the portfolio value now.

BE12:02pm

Memory chips that work like a bit like the magnetic element of hard drives, as I understand it, which I probably don't.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

And therefore don't need power to retain data.

BE12:03pm

The idea's existed for a very long time, but has been too expensive to push forward.

BE12:03pm

Numis sounds confident.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

STT is increasingly confident in its unique positioning in a $20bn+ market opportunity. The bridge will enable the company to execute through a critical period under its new leadership, where it begins to demonstrate the material benefits of its technology platform with potential commercial and strategic partners (where interest levels are already high). The completion of a Series B funding round, targeting strategic investors, is expected to conclude by the end of Q1 2018. Initial revenue is expected in 2018, which may include licensing of core technologies and full commercial product is expected from 2019.

BE12:05pm

So, demos over the next six months.

undefined
12:04 pm
PM12:05pm

Look at the time

PM12:06pm

BornCynic -- Federated Wireless. It had some fresh funding recently

PM12:06pm

But we are done for today

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Thanks Bryce

PM12:06pm

And cheers for joining us on the right

PM12:06pm

Back tomorrow

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Bye

PM11:34am

Apologies to those suffering tech problems -- and who won't see my apology until they read the transcript
